>5497/14/2015 1:40:40ManUkrainianEurope35-44Customer ResearchGood day to all who will read it!
Now I am in Odessa - is in Ukraine.

And I just need to work. I beg you to take seriously the facts set out below, even if they look like science fiction. But this banal truth.
First, somewhere else, in 1995 I had the CASIO electronic notebook and eventually I just decided to see what would happen if you press a different key without a specific purpose. And what is most interesting in it opened the card game, although this functionality, this notebook even under the instruction did not have. I know of at the time the card games, the rules did not comply. And even more after turning off all attempts to find this game failed.
The second, in 1999, bought in the United Arab Emirates terminal NOKIA 3210, by the way, my first terminal bought for their money. Scroll through all the menu, I was satisfied with the basic functions. However, I got the idea that the buttons are impractical and inconvenient, plus occupy most of the surface. Think of the screen should be over the entire surface, and a color touchscreen that should be the camera, player, GPS and the ability to expand the program part to the needs of any user. In 1999, the general came up with the concept of the iPhone. At that time, my name is officially written in English as a Yeremenko, and after a while, everyone in our family had to change all the documents, because the official name of that began to write as a Ieremenko. Although just Eremenko looks much more logical.
In 2000, the same terminal just lying on the table was the charge without being connected to any wires or. For 40 minutes, fully charged, and the battery will last for a week somewhere.
Then, the phone changes regularly and I do not even have to read the instructions, I already knew all of its functions.
As I am a skipper until 2008 and went to flight. He visited all continents and in many countries. He worked in international crews. And everywhere and always, I had a good relationship with the staff.
Once the family decided to give decided to go into business on land. I had a stationery shop, the first in Ukraine and Odessa. Also portal INteresNO.od.ua, used CMS JOOMLA. Accordingly I learned HTML and CSS. Once I worked as a driver in the cab. He was also hire children'
column1975:
s electric cars, selling boiled corn on the beach. Did the wiring in homes and apartments, installs and maintains air conditioning.
And the most interesting thing is that from 2010 to 2013 grew and sold marijuana. When in 2013 I was in a motorcycle accident (say straight out that under mysterious circumstances). And then with an open fracture on the foot (compound fracture, and even a piece of bone missing) even walked on his feet, the house he decided to treat the wound and realized that it is necessary to go to the trauma. First couple of days I was in the hospital, then went to the dressing periodically. And with the dressings everything is not so simple turned out, to the extent that the then forbidden to make bandages, and even decided to make a range of dressings for 5 days. Yes I do, something decided to listen. On day 3, I realized that nothing and when removed the bandage saw that becomes inflamed. And then ligation done every day as before.
And then when two months have passed, it is time to remove the needle and remove the plaster, solid fun began. X-rays, and according to the doctor it proved that the bones are not fused, and both need to do the operation and set the plate, and then again, and the operation to remove the plate, otherwise I can not walk. And this is in the Jewish Hospital and the Military Hospital. Even at home he wanted to pull the needle nose pliers, but in the hospital, at my insistent request still pulled needle, and for $ 50 or 400 hryvnia. And even after the doctor asked: Do you know what the most good operation, of course, I said that that which was not. And the doctor - no, that is avoided. But when I initially knew that the operation will not be. And the same situation with a fractured wrist on the hand, first said it in my wrist because of the crutches hurt when he still did X-rays and found broken in two places and shrapnel. The history began to repeat, even more fun.
I was offered three options for the operation. First, collect the broken bone, for stainless steel pin. Second, on the fiberglass. What a masterpiece, this is the third option, cut a piece of my ribs and make it a pin, which collect the bone. And, the third option of explaining the cheapest.
The result, the hand had healed itself, and the fragments resolved. And everything is fine with the leg, to develop and do not even bother.
Now begins the most interesting. I also used the hemp which is grown only on the day when the accident occurred was sober. But as long as there was in the cast she continued to smoke. However, probably out of boredom, he decided to get tested for IQ, online. After passing this test, I knew very important things. I completely changed mentality. Most importantly, the process is not reversible, in the sense of progress. What happened to me at the moment, you can neither buy nor achieve, can only receive and only on exam results, which was IQ test. When I started to take the test, you did not see the logic in the task, but has decided to continue to use and intuitive. And the intuition or sixth sense, as it is sometimes called, it is the totality of experience, all of the collective mind. This phenomenon has many different names intuition, gut feeling, the noosphere, egregor, astral, and so on. D., And so on. N.
And my feature is the absence of fear, but I know this term, I see a sense of meaning and purpose, but in my case it does not exist. I realized that I have my family, that I do not pay attention to her. He stopped to say abusive words. Stop using drugs (though still offer). My wife and I stopped swearing. So, too, ceased to grow. As much as three basic rules love, harmony and beauty.
His wife showed how ee mobile phone is turned on by my desire, as evidence even twice, as we sit in a taxi say that we have to the country. The driver turns off the phone, remove the battery, and we begin to travel around the city, and I control the movement.
This situation lasted for a week, as I said, I'

s chop all garbage, for my money. They asked how many of us and what we will do. Who I still know with such capabilities. column3460:
>8868/17/2015 9:03:15WomanHispanic/LatinoNorth America35-44HappinessIt would be a very boring place, this planet we call Earth, if all creatures were alike (both human and non-human). As a child and pre-teen growing up in Puerto Rico, there never seemed to be a divide regarding race and everyone was the same in the eyes of those who mentored me. Even within my own family we all differ in shades of skin color tremendously though we are all related. I grew up with that notion that it matters not if you have polka dots and horns, you were still included in the group.

Perhaps that is the utopian in me, but that was my upbringing, this was further validated through my Multicultural Counseling courses which taught me that people, could move through stages and achieve or find their identity. This was a refreshing way to view the world as people could identify as they wished, appreciate other cultures including the predominant culture (whichever it may be in their geographical area) and balance all aspects of their heritage. Again a very utopian way to look at the world, but it starts with one, right?

column3556: >9078/18/2015 11:21:12ManCaucasianNorth America25-34HappinessGrowing up in Elementary School through early High School, I was a bit of an outsider - primarily because I was so tall (6'
column3558: in 8th grade!) and as a byproduct, rather clumsy and awkward. That pain of being rejected by the &quot
column3560: minority made me a part of the majority of &quot
column3562:
people.

Thanks to the kindness of others reaching out to me, I changed from believing myself to be alone and an outcast from the cool kids and started to see myself as a member of a close-knit, highly protective (in a healthy way) group of rag-tag friends from various walks of life and social vulnerabilities. Thanks to the inclusion of my new "
column3564: (AKA: Kind, selfless, not-self-absorbed) friends, I came out of my shell and realized I was a bit of a comedian that resembled a mash up of Dick Van Dyke and Jim Carrey. More importantly though, I realized that everyone has a story (and often pains) and that everyone is important and deserves to enjoy the happiness I&#39
column3565:
d found in my band of eclectic friends.

Over time, my slap-stick comedy slowed a bit (most people call that maturity), but I did realize my calling: I love people and I love making them happy. Further though, I'
column3566:
ve learned that the only way to make others happy (and in turn, make me happy) is to be well-invested in growing as a human and improving and enriching my life with self-education and healthy introspection.

I'
column3567: m not done growing as a person (thankfully I am DONE in the physical height category!), which is why I need to be surrounded by diversity that challenges me and inclusivity that welcomes me. Im devoted to these concepts. These ideas changed my life.

column3595: >9138/18/2015 22:03:31WomanCaucasianAsia25-34Customer ResearchAs a university student I thought I understood what diversity and inclusivity meant from the school projects and student exchanges I had participated to. Only years later, after sharing our house with couchsurfers, starting to travel and moving to Asia did I begin to understand what diversity and inclusivity stood for at a bigger level ("
column3597:
would be too much said).
It was not just about people speaking different languages, having special traditions and eating customary food, but also about mentalities, cultural inheritance, egos and being able to accept and understand the people around you with different views.
China had offered me most lessons about diversity, from the huge number of people who come from different corners of the world and people who have various cultural backgrounds and live under the same political regime. India and Nepal were the first countries that showed me what inclusivity really stood for, with all their wonderful people who would share any small thing they had with a traveling stranger and inviting us to know more about their cultures as well as being curious to learn about ours.
One of the main idea I'
column3598: ve noticed is that people that don&#39
column3599: t put their ego in front are the ones that welcome the most diversity and inclusivity, while people who place their ego on a pedestal, most of the time, create a shield between them and other people who maybe just apparently don&#39
column3600: t share their ideas, therefore making diversity and inclusivity harder to attain.

column4193:
>10539/1/2015 2:11:16ManHispanic/LatinoEurope25-34DevelopmentMy Open Source Collaboration.

Actually, i share my knowledge with 2 main open source community:
- Laravel Italia, the best (and official) italian community about Laravel
Framework. I written a lot of articles about integration of design pattern in
Laravel 5. You could find them here. Also, there is an official repo group on
Github.
- PPUG (Palermo PHP User Group). I made recently a talk about GIT and DCVS.

You could find it here:
https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B0H8q4AGnlVXVWNZRVMwNmp0ems/view?usp=sharing

My Education.

I have a bachelor degree (with honors) in Computer Science. For about 5 years i
studied Object Oriented details and principles, like "
column4195:
from Gang
of Four book, SOLID Principles from Robert Martin and Architectural Pattern e
Martin Fowler'
column4197:
m a proud supporter of PHP language as a language
for enterprise applications. As proof of this, i developed a lot of applications.

My Experience.

In the last three years i worked for a local marketing company as Agile PHP
Developer and Project manager, where i used CodeIgniter and Laravel in a
professional manner. I developed a lot of web applications on CodeIgniter
framework (especially for study MVC pattern) and, after a year, i have begun to
insist to use Laravel as main PHP framework. Also, i collaborate with Laravel
Italia (stronger italian community of Laravel Italia) writing articles about Design
Pattern in PHP &
column4198:
Laravel Best practices.

RESTFul Interface (API).

In my work, I usually use to develop RESTFul Interface and i follow the best
standards (HTTP Status Code, Content-Type, well-formed JSON output) for
that.

I studied a lot of books about implementation and problem solving of RESTFul
Interface and i'
column4199:
ve collected a lot of tools to help me make my work more
productive. I follow Phil Sturgeon books like "
column4200: Build an API that you won&#39
column4202:
in Laravel 4.2-5. In my career, I developed RESTFul Interface for ESB (Enterprise
Service Bus) architecture, with sso (single sign on) or JWT authentication.

MySQL &
column4203:
MongoDB.

In my work, I usually use non-relational databases such as MongoDB and Redis
and in Laravel i use ORM like Eloquent (Moloquent is Eloquent for MongoDB:
https://github.com/jenssegers/laravel-mongodb) or Doctrine with design of
Entity Manager and Data Mappers classes to design a modular application, so i
have no problem with that.

Testing - TDD - BDD.

My studies have led me in the use of TDD ( test driven development ) with
PHPUnit and BDD with PHPSpec , who every day use to complete the
development of the builds of my projects . All this , of course , is orchestrated
by the use of Continuous Integration with Jenkins.

My Workflow.

In my work, it'
column4204:
s crucial to use versioning systems code, or rather Concurrent
Versions System (CVS) as GIT. The workflow I follow is described on git-flow
extensions package, It'
column4205:
s easily summarized here:
http://danielkummer.github.io/git-flow-cheatsheet/

My freetime.

In my free time, I LOVE playing my Gibson SG guitar and perform in the city
with my hard rock cover band. If you don'
column4206:
t know Scorpions, Journey or
Survivor, please take a look! :)

Why to hire me.

I '
column4207:
m ambitious, in the technical way. Ever since i was a child, i always loved the
software development world. Up to 5 years ago, i studied privately. When I
started working in a company, i got to show everyone my skills. I learned to
develop under deadlines, to respect deliveries and to hold positions of
Developer and Project Manager together, with no problem. Today, I am a
newcomer for this platform, but I really want to show my skills to you.
For this reason, I think I'
column4208:
m the right person for you. Anyway, thank you in
advance for your time.

column5158: >12719/20/2015 5:07:57ManEuropeanNorth America18-24HappinessGrowing up in a town that was a melting pot of ethnicities from around the globe, I never experienced living in a demographically homogenous area. As a result, diversity and inclusivity weren'
column5159:
t concepts that I was truly aware of as a kid, they were simply the norm. It was only after leaving the environment I grew up in that I came to truly understand how different mu upbringing was from the rest of the U.S.A. (and other parts of the world), and I appreciated it all the more.

The world is only getting smaller with each passing day, and with each new person I meet on my journey I am gently reminded of one simple truth: we are all humans striving to enjoy a fulfilling life. This idea, that was nurtured since my childhood, has had a significant role in the development of my patience, understanding, and appreciation of the differences between myself and others, as well as knowing when to celebrate and build upon our similarities.

Diversity and inclusivity, in my experience, have proven to be quintessential in my growth as a cooperative, amiable, and positive person in this life. :)

column5317:
>Gender non-conforming, androgynous, male-bodiedBlack/AfricanNorth America25-34ContentI also am interested in design.

Diversity and inclusivity? I'
column5318:
m learning that diversity begets more diversity. It can bring beautiful opportunities in workplaces as disagreements ultimately bring greater perspective an ways of problem solving.

I'
column5319: ll also say that part of the growth happening comes with people of more privileged backgrounds taking the time to listen and realize the perspectives being brought might not immediately &quot
column5321: to them. Women have knowledge men will never fully understand, especially in a male-dominated world. Women are required to have skills to navigate (just as trans and gender non-conforming people in relation to cisgender people) and have communal knowledge that men often don&#39
column5322: t enjoy because there usually isn&#39
column5323:
t public space for it. The same would be true in relation to people who hold racial supremacy in their country versus people who might night--which changes based on where you are in the world. There is also language divides and a post-industrial society versus developing country divide.

Over the years, I'
column5324: ve learned that we all are blinded by our privilege in some way. I went to a great university and until post-college didn&#39
column5325:
t realize how much more opportunity I had than others because of this fact. Until I payed conscious attention to what others were saying, I realized I sometimes presented academic knowledge in ways that might disenfranchise others.

Being around different people, that was diversity. Listening to them, learning from them, taking a back seat and opening myself up to be wrong, to be guilty, that was inclusion. I continue to challenge myself today by traveling to new places and making the first effort to become apart of them. These situations have helped me grow and take on skills that I didn'
column5326: t expect. I never want to stop pushing myself into these situations because being different has taught me more than being automatically accepted as apart of the group.

>13359/24/2015 15:33:09WomanCaucasianNorth America35-44CommunityI was interested in the Life Saver position but it is not included in the drop down box.

I am a southern mama of six boys. Three are from my first marriage that are grown and on their own. I remarried and I now have three younger boys who liven our lives and keep us on our toes. Accustomed to working with the diverse community of the mentally retarded and developmentally disabled children and adults I have encountered children and adults who are from all walks of life. The task with these children and adults was to get them out into the world so they could live as normally as possible, having friends, education and jobs. Allowing them to live their life to the fullest regardless of their disABILITIES.

I think this experience enlightened my life and was just as rewarding for me as I hope it was for the children and adults I worked with.

column5787:
>141510/6/2015 4:48:44WomanIndianAsia25-34Product
Being originally from small town in India,migrating to new residential schools for better quality education,working with MNC like Oracle Corporation across different divisions gave me a different perspective on my approach towards life.The understanding of new society, new customs, new lifestyle and a different work culture can be overwhelming experience at first, filled with excitement, confusion and anxiety. But Ultimately ,what i realized is we all are just people(humans) with same basic needs and values. The difference in opinions and our thoughts are just installed within us by the environment we grow up in. By experiencing, observing and adopting all the differences and similarities has been my most fascinating and valuable learning experience in my life.

Having a diversity in workplace regardless of personal demographics can really contribute to getting the best potential talent which leads to success and growth of an organisation. In my personal observation, a diverse environment in an organization definitely promotes a feeling of belongingness among different yet similar people.When we feel valued and respected, people in the organisation are likely to be much more engaged and productive.
I also think that employees can differentiate between a culture of inclusion from one of exclusion and that is exactly why workplace diversity and inclusive culture is important in any organization for survival and growth in todays global age.

Not many startups would take up the initiative to think different to have a diverse background of people working for them because of so many constraints and fear of acceptance. Its great to see startup firms like Buffer with values of openness, diversity so deeply imbibed and are trying to get awesome at it in this ever changing global age .
I am very happy to know that Buffer shares a belief in the culture of unity and inclusion and would look to be part of that unity someday soon.

>150510/12/2015 5:37:29WomanGreekEurope25-34ProductWe live in a society where color, gender or stereotypes based on basic properties of our human existence make peoples brain to expect less from itself.

I truly believe in fostering an inclusive (work or not) culture where uniqueness of beliefs, backgrounds, talents, capabilities, and ways of living are welcomed and leveraged. column7615:
>183010/30/2015 11:14:51ManIndianAsia18-24Happinessi) Diversity:-

Once an organization has successfully modified their recruitment and hiring practices to reach a more diverse audience, the next step is to successfully engage and support them as employees. In broad terms, diversity is any dimension that can be used to differentiate groups and people from one another. It means respect for and appreciation of differences in ethnicity, gender, age, national origin, disability, sexual orientation, education, and religion.

But its more than this. We all bring with us diverse perspectives, work experiences, life styles and cultures. As a source and driver of innovation, diversity is a big idea in business and in society.

ii) Inclusivity:-

Inclusion is a state of being valued, respected and supported. Its about focusing on the needs of every individual and ensuring the right conditions are in place for each person to achieve his or her full potential. Inclusion should be reflected in an organizations culture, practices and relationships that are in place to support a diverse workforce.

>188011/2/2015 23:28:06ManAustralianAustralia18-24HappinessI think that everyone should have the opportunity to be included, despite their background or beliefs. Being excluded can lead to depression and a feeling of hopelessness, and that people should be aware when other individuals around them are feeling this way in order to help them.

Diversity is an interesting term. I think that presenting oneself as unique can have benefits when such self-perception has been justified by positive actions, that in turn have been approved by a regulatory body, and that having a diverse range of personal interests or occupations can be stimulating. However I believe that actively trying to be diverse when the reasoning behind such hasn'
column7841:
t been recognised as above can lead to feelings of exclusion that, again, can lead to a negative state of mind when left to brood for too long. It can lead to an unwillingness to relate to others which in itself is a restricting activity.

I think diversity in terms of an object is good. Having multiple versions of a similar product or organism that differ slightly from each other can lead to inclusivity in terms of potential ways individuals can relate to one another, and that diversity provides solid evidence for evolution and/or intelligent design.

column8710: >208011/16/2015 7:36:30ManCaucasianNorth America25-34HappinessI'
column8711:
ve been ruminating on diversity and inclusivity quite a lot recently. Having attended one of the most liberal divinity schools in the US (Vanderbilt), these two ideals were very consistently preached upon (both in the literal and figurative sense). Being a male WASP, it was initially, a challenge to see the subtler, institutional side of racism, gender inequality, and the challenges facing the LGBTQI community.
Fortunately, I made many patient and loving friends whose stories illuminated these darker areas of American (and perhaps worldwide) society and allowed me to see those things that I had been blind to. I continue to grow, to see new things, to be challenged, to be frustrated with my own short-comings, and to learn how I can be an agent of change.

It is sad to know that some corporations do not enjoy sharing information to all of its employees because they feel that they should not know. column9210: >219211/24/2015 11:20:40ManHispanic/LatinxNorth America18-24HappinessAs a Hispanic man and legal US citizen in a large Mexican family, I can identify with those who lack a voice and who are here for a better and brighter future for thier families. As a Gay American man I can identify with those who struggle to be accepted for who they are. As a Dale Carnegie enthusiast I identify with few people who care to make the world a better, happier, and friendlier place. As a recent college graduate I can relate to those like me who are struggling to find entry level jobs due to the lack of 15+ years experience that is required. I recently started watching Transparent on Amazon and I have one thing to say- Everyone has issues, everyone is different, and no one is perfect. column9736: >American Native with Moorish descentNorth America35-44PeopleThe first experience I had regarding diversity and inclusivity was a diversity workshop hosted by Kraft foods in the early 90s. The workshop forced us to "
column9739: .   Prior to that, I did not realize how biased I was and many of us didn&#39
column9740: t realize how disrespectful we were to those that were different from us in regards to race, gender, sexual orientation, religion, and age. Also when I moved from my home town, I realized how segregated it was and was able to appreciate others talents from many diverse groups.  However, the most rewarding experience was being employed with two (2) Internationally known Fortune 500 companies.  I was 1 of 4 Americas in the first company and soon learned the perspective of non-Americans
column9741: it was humbling to say the least and allowed me to retire my ego.  The second organization showed me how inclusivity is essential to any company&#39
column9742: s growth and all members of an organization must be trained to implement tools, processes and projects that showcase diversity and inclusivity.

column10611:
>249712/11/2015 10:58:58ManWhiteNorth America25-34Content/MarketingI believe that diversity and inclusivity should not only include race and ethnic backgrounds, but societal and educational backgrounds as well. For example, many companies, whether they would like to admit it or not, discriminate against candidates without a college degree (people like me).

Don'
column10612: t get me wrong, there are plenty of careers in which a college education is completely necessary. However, there are just as many, if not more careers where experience can be even more valuable. I believe that in many cases companies miss out on opportunities to work with exceptional people because they don&#39
column10613: t have a piece of paper proving nothing more than the fact that you sat in a classroom and passed some tests (I&#39
column10614: m sure many college graduates did much more than that, but let&#39

>Black/African descentNorth America45-54CommunityI come from a small college town that has a history associated with the Underground Railroad. While the college tuition is $60,000 or more. my community struggles with 20% poverty, which is 5% above the national average. This is something I always try to keep in mind is a balance between those who have money and those who do not. I also currently serve as a member of Oberlin City Council where I must weigh in on the diverse community issues all the time. In addition, my current job as Program Coordinator is about sustainability and environment and economy through the lens of social justice. I find this type of work to be challenging and exciting!

column13378: ve been providing. From my perspective, I&#39
column13379: ve never really thought much about diversity challenges because I don&#39
column13380: t personally label people based on demographics. It makes zero difference to me what someone is when it comes to race, age, gender etc., any of it. I connect with people for who they are, not what they&#39
column13381: re labelled (whether the label is self-imposed or externally). But through the information that Buffer has been providing, I&#39
column13382:
m learning how those labels do present concerns for some people in different ways.

It even turns out that being a single mom in her 40'
column13383: s, is apparently a diversity group of its own - who knew? Lol. I was oblivious to this being a concern for some - despite the fact that it&#39
column13384:
s exactly the category that I fall into. :-)

I think the only area that I'
column13385: ve really struggled to understand the relevance of is certain sexuality preferences. Gender roles as determined by biological make up is one thing. But when it comes to areas of sexuality that really just come down to a personal choice, I&#39
column13386: m not so sure that it&#39
column13387: s necessary to put it on display. Basically, what people choose to engage in with their recreational, sexual activity is a private matter in my opinion. Next thing we&#39
column13388:

Other than that, I think the Buffer approach and attitude towards diversity is awesome. :-)

column19038:
m a multi-racial, single mother and have spent the majority of my life interacting with people from every stage of life. Young, old, employed, homeless, financially well-off and destitute. At the end of the day, it is my belief that we all deserve the same basic respect and appreciation. We all need to be heard. We all want to be understood. We all deserve to be treated fairly and equally, regardless of age, race, national origin, sexual identification, religion, creed or socio-economic background.

Discovering Buffer not only employs people with the same philosophy - but operates it'
column19039: s business model with those same principles - has given me an inspired appreciation for and hope in the future of businesses across the globe. Thank you.

column22708:
>White/CaucasianI doI doNorth America25-34HappinessDiversity and inclusivity is a large part of the activist career, and my passion to expand grow more each day. I donate my time to the Woodhull Sexual Freedom Alliance, working as Leadership Chairing their Accessibility Committee. My tireless work to make our yearly Sexual Freedom Summit as inclusive and accessible has been an incredible joy while opening my eyes to how far we need to go to meet our goals.

I am a cisgendered white woman with invisible disabilities, partnered to a neurodiverse disabled nonbinary partner. We'
column22709:
re both queer. Beyond the basics of making our space mobility devices friendly and creating quiet rooms for folks to find quiet and solace, much of what we do is reaching out to folks in a passionately positive way to let them know that we value their voices. Value their work. We want to step back and make more space for minority voices to be heard, and be heard loudly and strongly. Proudly. While we stand behind in solidarity and support.

This has worked and is working more and more as our summits are now bringing in some of the most diverse line up of speakers in our industry. Still, no where near where we want to be. Constant Joyful Improvement.
column22711: >That's cool with me
